captions.text:
Good morning Hank, it's Tuesday. Old school
vlogbrothers video where I sit down with no

idea what I'm going to talk about.. about,
what I'm going to talk - whatever, sometimes
you need to end a sentence with a preposition.

Okay, so a while ago I was getting dressed
for a cocktail party and I was putting on

like, proper fancy pants and everything, and
I was looking at myself in the mirror, and

I said to Sarah, "I feel like I look like
a middle aged man in this outfit". And then

Sarah paused for like a quarter second too
long before saying, "Nonono you look great!"

And I realized, I look like a middle aged
man, because I am a middle aged man.

Like if I die at double my current age, people
won't be like, "Oh, it's a tragedy", they'll

be like, "Nyehh, he had a good run. Coulda
been better, wasn't terrible".

My theory about middle age is that if you
triple your current age, and that's like a

reasonable age for a human being to be, then
you're not yet middle aged. I mean Hank you're

33, you triple that you're 99, that's right
on the edge. I'm 36, you're triple that, that's

108. Living to 108 doesn't even seem like
a good outcome to me. Anyway, there are tons

of obviously negative things about being middle
aged, but there are also some advantages,

you know, like the stability of adulthood,
and the pleasure of parenting.

But the biggest thing, Hank, is that no one
expects me to know anything about pop culture,
which is great because I don't.
And this brings us, belatedly, to Justin Bieber.

To be honest with you, Hank, I know this sounds
crazy, but I don't think I've ever heard a

Justin Bieber song. Actually, I'm gonna listen
to like his top 5 songs right now, and see
if I've ever heard any of them. Hold on.

Okay, this one's called "Boyfriend". It has
like, 3 hundred million views. I haven't heard

this song before. It's kinda good. Is he a
rapper? It's a good song, I never heard it

before though. Alright, lets see the next
one.

Okay, this one's called uh, this one's called
"One Time". Oh he looks much younger in this

video. I kinda like this one as well. Although
he just rhymed "knock" with "stop". Yeah,
I never heard that song before in my life.

Okay, let's see what's next. "Beauty and da
Beat", featuring Nicki Minaj. Nope. Uh, I
have never heard "Beauty and da Beat".

I'm only gonna try one more. It's the most
viewed one ever. It's called "Baby" and it

features Ludacris. This seems familiar to
me. I feel like I have heard this song before.

I feel like I've heard it, but I feel like
I've heard a cover of it or something? Anyway,

that one is definitely familiar. "Baby" featuring
Ludacris is familiar to me.

So there you have it, I've heard one Justin
Bieber song, I think.
And yet.

Despite my obvious and complete ignorance
of Justin Bieber and his work, I can tell

you that Justin Bieber was recently arrested
for DUI, driving a rented Lamborghini, and

in fact, I can tell you the color of that
Lamborghini: it was yellow.

Why do I know this, Hank? Non-rhetorical question.
Why do I know about it? I have no investment

in Justin Bieber, I mean I don't think he
should drink and drive, but I don't think

anyone should drink and drive. Why do I know
the color of that Lamborghini? Why do I have

the image of Britney Spears' shaved head imprinted
upon my mind where I might be remembering,
I don't know, how to speak Dutch or something.

So Hank, I feel like a relatively small number
of people raises someone up to the level of

celebrity, and then everyone gets to participate
in like, relishing their downfall. It seems

to me that Justin Bieber is now more likely
to be on the cover of tabloid magazines than

he was back when he was doing really well,
like in the "Baby" era--

OHHHHHHH! "Baby"! It's from your song Hank!
The "Ice Cream Changes" song, I know it because

of your song! If you don't know what I'm talking
about, link in the Doobly-doo. But Hank, I

haven't heard that Justin Bieber song, I only
heard your cover of it. I'm still zero for

Bieber! Or, I was, until I listened to those
songs anyway, which I quite liked.

Hank, I don't want to excuse anyone's behaviour,
and I certainly don't want to act like celebrity

is the most troubling form of oppression out
there. But I do worry about the way we approach

celebrities' problems with relish. Not so
much because it's bad for the celebrities,
but because I think it might be bad for us.

I don't think relentless public chastising
much helps anyone. If it did, we would see
this happen less, and we aren't.

Hank, it's really hard to choose what we pay
attention to, but I think in a lot of ways

it's also one of the most important choices
we make.

So here's to sober driving, imagining others
complexly, and not paying attention to the
color of someone else's rented Lamborghini.
Hank, I'll see you on Friday.

I hate it when people, who have never had Justin Bieber do anything to that

comments.author: jordan goldbloom

comments.text:
You are technically middle aged when you turn 30.  You are in old age when 
you turn 60.  I saw my first grey hair at 30.  A woman has 10% of her eggs 
left when she turns 30 and 3% when she turns 40, which is considered 
clinical menopause.  A person is considered young in his/her 20's.  That's 
a "young man", a "young woman."  Most people have a midlife crisis at 35, 
wondering if they can still attract the opposite sex like they used to.  
Wait until you hit 40.  Your teeth become sensitive to hot and cold, your 
eyesight loses it's elasticity and you become permanently far-sighted,  
your metabolism changes, and your face takes on a more mature look. ﻿

comments.text:
You remember that it's yellow because Jay Gatsby also had a yellow luxury 
car. Yellow represents the fake wealthy people that allegedly live the 
American Dream in the novel. Gatsby and Bieber both fit the description of 
being the people who built wealth in a recent period of time, or as the 
novel depicts, the "new rich". They have a lot more in common when you get 
into the details of both their lives. I just thought that pointing out the 
comparison would shed some light :). ﻿

comments.text:
My biggest problem with the Justin Bieber bad boy phenomenon is that he has 
so many apologists. Yes, he is young, but how many other kids his age would 
have people trying to justify their behavior if they had done this? How 
many would have tried to justify it if he had gotten into an accident? Hurt 
somebody? Killed somebody? Granted he didn't (this time) but by lowering 
his ability to control a vehicle, then driving it through a populated area 
at illegal speeds shows that he needs a wake up call - not excuses made for 
him.﻿

comments.author: Sarah c:

comments.text:
Also: it is not INCORRECT or 'non-standard' in descriptive linguistic terms 
to end a sentence with a preposition. I think it was Mulcaster? In the 
prescriptive era of the English language, 1700's or 1800's, he wrote a 
'grammar', and said that it was preferable to ending with a preposition but 
not obligatory. He was around the same people like Johnson (wrote the 
occasionally anti-Scot dictionary) - people who wanted to pin down the 
English language because they felt that - like French - it shouldn't 
change. Which didn't really work. Because technology. And, like, the French 
basically ignore the Academy anyway. So. While stuff *feels* wrong, it 
probably isn't. And no one's going to tell you otherwise - unless they 
can't understand it.
Actually, good point - how pedantic are publishers about grammar and stuff, 
anyway?﻿

comments.text:
If i can also add...People need to stop looking to celebrities to be role 
models for their children.  They are flawed human beings just like everyone 
else except they have way more money.  As a 20 year old young man, he is 
doing exactly what he is supposed to be doing...he is young and is supposed 
to be making mistakes he can look back on in the future and go "What the 
F**K was i thinking?" Except he has way more money than the average young 
person.  But he needs to be making mistakes right now...everyone up his 
behind with a microscope and telling him what he shouldn't be doing is not 
going to move him one bit. And this goes for all the other celebs too.   
Its not their place to raise our children, it is ours.﻿

Hey Tom, Hey Hank.  I have been following you guys for about a year.  I 
enjoy all of your stuff. Tom, I am way older than you.  You are not a 
middle aged man, you're just a grown ass man.  I don't know Justin's music 
that much either, doesn't make him good or bad but in my opinion there 
isn't much great music out there anymore as far as pop music goes. So it 
doesn't make you out of touch or old...just a grown ass man with way more 
cooler things to do than know who Justin Bieber is. I was a teen in the 
80's and a young adult in the early nineties when it was a lot more cooler 
pop music and not to mention Hip Hop, Rock, Metal and the great genres. 
Again this is just my opinion Keep rockin your vids.﻿

It is about gossip.
People like to gossip about people they know in common.
In a small town they  know everyone so it is all good but in modern cities 
people have fewer people in common so having people everyone knows is 
helpful. THis is why we have soap operas, Charles Dickens an the pantheon 
of Gods/biblical figures.

Have you read the Bible? It is a huge soap opera. So are Greek and Norse 
myths. 

People in them have a reputation. Do you know what is reputation? It is 
people talking, is gossip.﻿

comments.text:
Technically rhyming "knock" with "stop" is assonance (rhyming vowel sounds) 
which kinda counts?﻿
comments.author: Josh H

comments.text:
+Sophia Burke It's called a half rhyme which can be achieved using a 
variety of methods, on of them being assonance. A large majority of poets 
use half rhymes. It's honestly not something I would ever think to actually 
fault Jusin Bieber (/the actual writer of the song) on versus the rest of 
the lyrics
comments.author: Rufus Driscoll

comments.text: Assonance is the repetition of vowel sounds.
